Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Understanding and Improving Collegiate Persistence and STEM Opportunities for Developmental Mathematics Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nationally, approximately half of all students entering college are placed into developmental mathematics courses, which focus on basic arithmetic and pre-algebra topics. In addition, often, the credit hours for developmental mathematics courses do not count toward college graduation hours. Some undergraduates who place into developmental mathematics are interested in pursuing a career in STEM, but get discouraged because they had to start their degree trajectory at the developmental course level. At the same time, the ongoing need for a strong workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) makes it important not to lose so many students who started college with an interest in STEM. In Fall 2015, for the first time, the developmental mathematics course at West Virginia University (WVU) will carry credit-bearing weight, offering a special opportunity to study the impact of this change on student success in the course and persistence in subsequent STEM courses.

Building on current work being conducted at WVU across STEM disciplines based on early studies of self-identity situated in disciplines, this project will address the following questions: (1) In what ways do students in developmental mathematics self-identify as STEM learners? (2) At what rate do STEM-intending developmental mathematics students persist in pursuit of a STEM degree? (3) Does a shift to a credit-bearing version of developmental mathematics improve student success rates? (4) What are the factors in developmental mathematics that contribute to (i) persistence as a STEM major and (ii) self identification as STEM learners? (5) How will the introduction of peer mentors affect the learning gains of developmental students? Using survey and institutional data, the project team will track students through their first two years of their degree programs to investigate when and why developmental mathematics students switch out of STEM majors, as well as to identify factors related to student persistence in STEM from this remedial starting point.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. More than one third of all STEM-intending students in the U.S. enroll in mathematics remediation (Radford et al., 2012) and, despite recent rapid growth of enrollment in STEM disciplines, the number of students graduating with a STEM degree remains relatively stagnant due to diminishing student retention rates (Thompson & Bolin, 2011; Hurtado, Eagan & Chang, 2010). The project team collected data from students in an effort to gain insight into the way affective states such as anxiety impact student success and persistence in a developmental mathematics course. In addition, a peer mentoring intervention was developed and implemented in an effort to improve student success and persistence and to study the way this program interacted with students’ persistence over time.

           

Survey and institutional demographic data was collected over a two-year period starting in Fall 2015. More than 1000 students in the developmental course were surveyed about career exploration experiences and anxiety levels and the group of students are subsequently being tracked in order to analyze persistence in STEM degrees. 

 

Intellectual Merit. The two main activities of the project consisted of conducting a two­year collection of student responses to a set of surveys that measured the affective state and personality traits of students along with the development of a peer­mentoring intervention intended to increase student success and persistence in a developmental mathematics course. Survey instruments were offered to 2470 students in the developmental mathematics course over four semesters that measured the level of anxiety and personality traits of students. In addition, the STEM identity, STEM persistence level, self­efficacy and career intention of the students were measured using a collection of likert­scale questions in three additional survey instruments. Of these students, approximately 1000 consented and returned at least one of the instruments in our collection. This data was aggregated along with other demographic data such as gender, race/ethnicity, placement scores and first­generation status. Student majors were recorded and compared to their major choice in subsequent semesters during the duration of the project. Their major choice will be evaluated longitudinally in the future up to graduation to determine the long-term outcome for STEM intending and other students. The peer-mentoring component was piloted in Fall 2016 and offered to 87 students in Spring 2017. Materials were developed to support the peer mentors who were assigned groups of students. A collection of planned activities was conducted during the course of each semester and outcomes measured.

 

The data collected from the surveys along with underlying student demographic data and initial results have been analyzed and student success outcomes compared to the underlying student characteristics. Preliminary results indicate that for the entire cohort of students the grade point average from the course depends statistically significantly on total anxiety (p<.0001 with R2=.087) and on the average of all likert responses in the self­efficacy instrument (p<.0001 with R2=.37) using a univariate ANOVA. The levels with which these results are borne out in the case of each individual semester needs additional analysis to determine. In addition, students in the treatment group receiving peer-mentoring succeeded at a rate that was ten percentage points higher than either the control group or the larger population of students. Ongoing work is being conducted to develop models of student STEM intention at this level and to implement the peer-mentoring process on a larger scale.

 

Broader Impacts. This work has contributed to the knowledge base surrounding the following aspects of the oft-overlooked group of STEM-intending developmental mathematics students: (1) how they perceive themselves as STEM learners, (2) how they arrived at their originally intended majors (what level of career exploration they incurred before declaring a major, what their expectations of that career are, etc.) and how committed they are to those majors by tracking their persistence in those programs, and (3) their content mastery and anxiety levels and how those correlate to their identities as STEM learners. The project has added to the knowledge base on peer mentoring in the context of developmental mathematics courses at a large research university. The outcomes of this project inform both local recruitment and retention as well as provide analytical models that can be extended to more traditional two-year to four-year feeder programs, allowing these programs to increase STEM majors in a number of fields. The insight provided can be transferred to numerous institutions nationally that seek to provide effective pathways into STEM careers for at-risk students.
